facts.text: 26 accused were charged with offences under Sections 307/149, 304/34, 147, 148 and 379

anchor.surface_text: Of the 26 accused charged with offences under Sections 307/149, 304/34, 147, 148 and 379, the Trial Court acquitted 24 accused but convicted Nanhku Singh, A-1 and Lalita Singh, A-2 under Section 307 and sentenced the former to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and the latter to 5 years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Trial Court acquitted 24 accused

anchor.surface_text: the Trial Court acquitted 24 accused but convicted Nanhku Singh, A-1 and Lalita Singh, A-2 under Section 307 and sentenced the former to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and the latter to 5 years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Trial Court convicted Nanhku Singh A-1 under Section 307 and sentenced him to 7 years rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: but convicted Nanhku Singh, A-1 and Lalita Singh, A-2 under Section 307 and sentenced the former to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and the latter to 5 years rigorous imprisonment. In appeal the High Court confirmed the conviction of both the accused but under Section 307 read with Section 34 and reduced the sentences to be undergone by each by them to 3 years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Trial Court convicted Lalita Singh A-2 under Section 307 and sentenced her to 5 years rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: and Lalita Singh, A-2 under Section 307 and sentenced the former to 7 years rigorous imprisonment and the latter to 5 years rigorous imprisonment. In appeal the High Court confirmed the conviction of both the accused but under Section 307 read with Section 34 and reduced the sentences to be undergone by each by them to 3 years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction of Nanhku Singh and Lalita Singh under Section 307 read with Section 34 and reduced sentences to 3 years rigorous imprisonment each

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the High Court confirmed the conviction of both the accused but under Section 307 read with Section 34 and reduced the sentences to be undergone by each by them to 3 years rigorous imprisonment. This Court granted Special leave only to Nanhku Singh and rejected the petition of Lalita Singh for default of surrender.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave only to Nanhku Singh and rejected petition of Lalita Singh for default of surrender

anchor.surface_text: This Court granted Special leave only to Nanhku Singh and rejected the petition of Lalita Singh for default of surrender. According to the prosecution case, on November, 17, 1964 at about one Pahar after sun-rise, about 7 or 8 A.M.

facts.text: On November 17, 1964 at about one Pahar after sun-rise, about 7 or 8 A.M., Nanhku Singh, Mohan Singh A-3 with guns, accused Nos. 4 to 26 armed with ballams, Garashas and lathis came to the field of Indradeo Singh PW 12 and cut the paddy crop

anchor.surface_text: According to the prosecution case, on November, 17, 1964 at about one Pahar after sun-rise, about 7 or 8 A.M. Nanhku Singh, Mohan Singh, A-3 who had each a gun, along with accused Nos. 4 to 26 who were armed with ballams, Garashas and lathis came to the field of Indradeo Singh, PW 12 and were alleged to be engaged in cutting the peddy crop in that field.

facts.text: Indradeo Singh along with Chait Ahir PW 8 and others went to the field and Indradeo Singh protested

anchor.surface_text: On seeing this, Indradeo Singh along with Chait Ahir, PW 8 and others went there and when Indradeo Singh protested at the High handedness of the accused there was an altercation between him and the party of the accused whereupon Nanhku Singh shot Indradeo Singh - This was followed by Mohan Singh also firing at Indradeosingh.

facts.text: Nanhku Singh shot Indradeo Singh

anchor.surface_text: there was an altercation between him and the party of the accused whereupon Nanhku Singh shot Indradeo Singh - This was followed by Mohan Singh also firing at Indradeosingh. Indradeosingh was injured after which he fell down in the field of sumersingh situated in the north of his own field separated by a small plot of Jamus Singh and water nala.

facts.text: Mohan Singh fired at Indradeo Singh

anchor.surface_text: Nanhku Singh shot Indradeo Singh - This was followed by Mohan Singh also firing at Indradeosingh. Indradeosingh was injured after which he fell down in the field of sumersingh situated in the north of his own field separated by a small plot of Jamus Singh and water nala.

facts.text: Chait Ahir went to rescue Indradeo Singh but Lalita Singh fired and caused injuries to Chait Ahir

anchor.surface_text: After Indradeo Singh fell down, Chait Ahir went to his rescue and wanted to lift him but Lalita Singh fired and caused him injuries On hearing these gun shots some nearly persons came there when the accused ran away alter taking the harvested paddy.

facts.text: Accused ran away after taking the harvested paddy

anchor.surface_text: On hearing these gun shots some nearly persons came there when the accused ran away alter taking the harvested paddy. Dina Nath, PW 21 who was cutting his paddy crop in the field situated near Indradeo Singhs field, on hearing the gun shots came to the scene and witnessed the shooting of Chait Ahir.

facts.text: Dina Nath PW 21 was cutting his paddy crop near Indradeo Singh's field, heard gun shots, came to scene, witnessed shooting of Chait Ahir

anchor.surface_text: Dina Nath, PW 21 who was cutting his paddy crop in the field situated near Indradeo Singhs field, on hearing the gun shots came to the scene and witnessed the shooting of Chait Ahir. He placed Indradeo Singh on a cot and he along with others took him to the Police Station, about 8 miles away.

facts.text: Dina Nath placed Indradeo Singh on a cot and took him with others to Police Station about 8 miles away

anchor.surface_text: He placed Indradeo Singh on a cot and he along with others took him to the Police Station, about 8 miles away. There about 2 p.m. Dina Nath lodged a first information Report because Indradeo Singh was number fully companyscious and was unable to speak.

facts.text: About 2 p.m. on November 17, 1964, Dina Nath lodged first information report because Indradeo Singh was unconscious and unable to speak

anchor.surface_text: There about 2 p.m. Dina Nath lodged a first information Report because Indradeo Singh was number fully companyscious and was unable to speak. The injured persons were then sent to the Durgawati Hospital for their medical examination where they were attended by Doctor Aggarwal.

issues.text: Whether this Court should interfere with the concurrent findings of the Trial Court and High Court on appreciation of evidence convicting the appellant under Section 307 read with Section 34 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Both the Trial Court as well as the Appellate Court were aware of the need to exercise caution and after weighing the evidence carefully and giving the utmost benefit to the accused nonetheless came to the conclusion that the offence against both the appellant and the other accused had been established. This Court does not ordinarily interfere with the findings arrived at on an appreciation of evidence by the High Court particularly when it affirms the finding of the Trial Court unless the conclusions arrived at cannot be supported by the evidence or that it is perverse.

issues.text: Whether the testimony of eyewitnesses is reliable despite admitted enmity between the parties

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the evidence that there was enmity between the father of the appellant Ambika Singh and Indradeo Singh, PW 12, Chait Ahir, PW 8, Dina Nath, PW 11, Mushan Pandey PW 7. Ambika Singh initiated proceedings under Section 107, Cr.P.C. against Bilar Ahir PW 3, Mushan Pandey, PW 7, Chait Ahir, PW 8, Dina Nath, PW 11 and Indradeo Singh, PW 12. It also appears that in a case brought against PW 3 by Ghureher Gareri, accused Mohan Singh and Ambika Singh had given evidence and though he was convicted by the Trial Court, the Appellate Court acquitted him. In view of the admitted ill feelings between Ambika Singh Mohan Singh some of the witnesses including Indradeo Singh and Chait Ahir, the evidence of the eye witness has to be scrutinised carefully.

issues.text: Whether the appellant deserves the same benefit of acquittal as Mohan Singh on the same evidence

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the appellant has sought to contend that on the same evidence Mohan Singh was acquitted by the Trial Court and that benefit should have also given to the appellant and the other accused. This submission does not take into account that there was no appeal against acquittal of Mohan Singh and the High Court was not called upon to make an appreciation of the evidence on the relative culpability of the two accused.

holdings.text: This Court does not ordinarily interfere with the findings arrived at on an appreciation of evidence by the High Court particularly when it affirms the finding of the Trial Court unless the conclusions arrived at cannot be supported by the evidence or that it is perverse. We do not think this is a case of that kind where our interference is called for.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Trial Court as well as the Appellate Court were aware of the need to exercise caution and after weighing the evidence carefully and giving the utmost benefit to the accused nonetheless came to the conclusion that the offence against both the appellant and the other accused had been established. holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts aware of enmity, exercised caution, weighed evidence carefully, gave benefit of doubt to accused, still found offence proved; findings not perverse or unsupported.

holdings.text: In view of the admitted ill feelings between Ambika Singh Mohan Singh some of the witnesses including Indradeo Singh and Chait Ahir, the evidence of the eye witness has to be scrutinised carefully. Both the Trial Court as well as the Appellate Court were aware of the need to exercise caution and after weighing the evidence carefully... came to the conclusion that the offence... had been established.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the evidence that there was enmity between the father of the appellant Ambika Singh and Indradeo Singh, PW 12, Chait Ahir, PW 8, Dina Nath, PW 11, Mushan Pandey PW 7. Ambika Singh initiated proceedings under Section 107, Cr.P.C. against Bilar Ahir PW 3, Mushan Pandey, PW 7, Chait Ahir, PW 8, Dina Nath, PW 11 and Indradeo Singh, PW 12.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Despite admitted enmity and proceedings under S.107 CrPC, lower courts scrutinized eyewitness testimony carefully and found it reliable after weighing probabilities.

holdings.text: This submission does not take into account that there was no appeal against acquittal of Mohan Singh and the High Court was not called upon to make an appreciation of the evidence on the relative culpability of the two accused.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the appellant has sought to contend that on the same evidence Mohan Singh was acquitted by the Trial Court and that benefit should have also given to the appellant and the other accused. This submission does not take into account that there was no appeal against acquittal of Mohan Singh and the High Court was not called upon to make an appreciation of the evidence on the relative culpability of the two accused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No appeal filed against acquittal of Mohan Singh, so High Court did not assess comparative culpability; cannot extend benefit without such adjudication.

holdings.text: We do not think it is open to the learned advocate to comment upon it because none of those contradictions have been put to the witness at the time of his giving evidence... F.I.R. is not a substantial piece of evidence. It is an information of a cognizable offence given under Section 154 of the Criminal Procedure Code and if there is any statement made therein it can only be used for the purposes of contradicting and discrediting a witness under Section 145 of the Evidence Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Contradictions not put to witness in cross-examination; FIR not substantive evidence but only first information under CrPC S.154, usable for contradiction under Evidence Act S.145 only.

holdings.text: We do not think there is any validity in this submission because the investigating Officer Rang Nath Prasad, P.W. 13... says that he could not record the statement of Indradeo Singh because he was in pain and could not speak... The evidence of P.W. 13 is corroborated by the fact that there was a punctured wound on the left prominence of the cheek 8/10 x 1/2 with everted and irregular edges and another wound of 1/2 x 1/10 x 1/2 situated 1/5 below the right lobule of the ear.
holdings.reasoning_summary: IO PW13 testified Indradeo unable to speak due to pain on day of incident; no challenge in cross; corroborated by nature of gunshot injuries to face.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think this is a case of that kind where our interference is called for.

edges.explanation: The holding directly resolves the issue by stating the principle of non-interference with concurrent findings on evidence appreciation.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Trial Court as well as the Appellate Court were aware of the need to exercise caution and after weighing the evidence carefully and giving the utmost benefit to the accused nonetheless came to the conclusion that the offence against both the appellant and the other accused had been established. This Court does not ordinarily interfere with the findings arrived at on an appreciation of evidence by the High Court particularly when it affirms the finding of the Trial Court unless the conclusions arrived at cannot be supported by the evidence or that it is perverse.
We do number think this is a case of that kind where our interference is called for.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the evidence that there was enmity between the father of the appellant Ambika Singh and Indradeo Singh, PW 12, Chait Ahir, PW 8, Dina Nath, PW 11, Mushan Pandey PW 7. anchor.surface_text: The learned Advocate for the appellant has sought to contend that on the same evidence Mohan Singh was acquitted by the Trial Court and that benefit should have also given to the appellant and the other accused. This submission does not take into account that there was no appeal against acquittal of Mohan Singh and the High Court was not called upon to make an appreciation of the evidence on the relative culpability of the two accused.
We do number think this is a case of that kind where our interference is called for.
